I found Dr. Gutting's article inspiring and most these responses discouraging. Sure, his ideas are idealistic. Sure, the American people tend to watch more "mindless" stuff on TV. By the same token, Americans are just as smart as people in other countries, such as France or the UK, where critical thinking and debate are lauded. It's a matter of values, and if enough people (e.g. Gutting and all of us readers) demand something more substantive than our current model and work to institute it, Americans may just rise to the occasion. At the very least, it would send a message that says: this stuff is important, and we're going to do it, whether or not you find it riveting. And it just might expose Americans to the process or argument and critical thinking, something sadly lacking in all discourse here.

I also think many Americans are sick of superficial political discourse. This is why Americans are not engaged. This is why Americans throw their hands up and say, "Well, all politicians lie," without bothering to uncover the truth. If a forum for substantive debate was enacted, what harm could possibly come from it? I can't think of any. And I can think of a lot of positives that could be accomplished.

These reader comments remind me of comments from those who oppose any and all gun control, under the premise of "it'll never work." Well, of course it won't work if we don't try! And even if it doesn't work, it sends a message that communicates what we value in our society.

Shane Keller was a combat photographer in the Marine Corps, so he was indeed a soldier. Military photographers are typically non-combatants, though, so calling Keller a former "sniper" is a bit like saying whoever processes the SEAL Team 6 payroll in Navy human resources was part of the team which killed Osama bin Laden.

Thank you for your commitment to hearing out all sides of the story. As I see it, though, the issue here is not what happened at Shane Keller's apartment. It is whether this image is what a reasonable viewer would take it to be. In the context of the portfolio it had to be seen as a document of a high crime inner city neighborhood in Rochester. The World Press Photo submission which includes it is titled “The Crescent” and the text describes that area of Rochester and its problems. Indeed, Mr. Pellegrin’s text claims that the images were made there, which in the case of Mr. Keller’s image was not the case. Shane lived in a suburban town about 20 minutes away from the Crescent. He was not associated in any way with that area or its problems.

If Pellegrin was trying to make a point about the connection between gun culture and inner city violence this is not evident from the edit, captions, or supporting text. The image looks like the same kind of documented moment captured in the other eleven images in this story. It is not that, and Pellegrin's response never claims that it was.

No later explanation can eliminate this gap between what the image was claimed to be and what it objectively shows. I regret that we did not contact the photographer, because of the distress it may have caused and because the debate over this issue distracts from the real question. After reading Mr. Pellegrin’s responses today, however, I see no reason to take back anything in the Bagnews story.

"'I find this all a little bit ridiculous,' Mr. Pellegrin said. 'I don’t understand what the big controversy is about. He mentions that I didn’t mention his name. I forgot his name. I don’t know how many people — how many situations, that day, that week, those two weeks that I was there — when I went back home, yes, I forgot his name. What I remember was that he was a former soldier.'"

That's why journalists take notes. Like all journalists, photojournalists should always be prepared to defend their work if challenged. The fact a photojournalist of Mr. Pellegrin's stature apparently didn't bother making any meaningful notes about his subject, whether contemporaneously or after the fact, is something I find shocking. That fact coupled with Mr. Keller's unrefuted assertion the photographer wasn't even interested in knowing his subject's name when it was volunteered — much less bothering to write it down — is something I find extremely troubling as a photojournalist.

I also find it troubling Mr. Pellegrin would shoot a portrait of a photojournalism student who happens to be a former Marine Corps photographer, identify him as a "former Marine sniper" and then flippantly say it's "a little bit ridiculous" having his ethics questioned when he's called out for committing a major factual error. Mr. Pellegrin's apparent sloppiness as a journalist is what's ridiculous, IMHO.

I have never been a fan of Gus Johnson's. During his time covering the Knicks, I always felt he was trying to hard and felt he was yelling half the time.

That being said, he has done a decent job during his first two games, and hopefully he'll continue to improve and get to know the beautiful game.

Nothing against Gus Johnson, but FOX should know better.

They have direct knowledge of what ESPN experienced when they tried the colossally bad Dave O'Brien/Marcelo Balboa 2006 World Cup debacle.

It's not being a snob, it's simply wanting the broadcaster to have the depth of experience on the subject. Gus doesn't have that for soccer, nor---to the point made by L.G. and RL---does Martin Tyler have that for the NFL.

I've seen each of the games Johnson has done, and aside from an audible "Oh, no!" when the announcers come on the screen, I haven't had much occasion to yell at the screen for anything he has said (just the occasional eye-rolling).

But "not as bad as I expected" is faint praise indeed. I much prefer *any* of the British announcers, especially the ESPN team of Ian Darke and Steve McManaman.
